entry.title: Issue 22 - 20th May 2011
entry.content:
Issue 22 – 20th May 2011

More articles worth reading, events worth attending and tools worth investigating. If only I had time to try out all of the things everyone is publishing or discussing.

News

The next Devopsdays Europe has a date, Friday 14th and Saturday 15th of October 2011, to go along with the location of Goteborg in Sweden. They are still looking for sponsors so if that’s you be sure to get in touch with the organisers.

http://www.devopsdays.org/events/2011-goteborg/

Pro Puppet is out. James Turnbull has written a follow up to the first Puppet book, this time with much more content and with an index (sorry James). It covers getting started all the way through to using MCollective. Apologies for the affiliate link, it helps pay the bills.

https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/1430230576/tag=devobook-21

This is the first PDF link I’ve included I think, but it’s worth it. The Operating Systems Division of The National Security Agency has published a whopping 200 page guide to the Secure Configuration of Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5. If this is a topic you need to know about this looks perfect.

http://www.nsa.gov/ia/_files/os/redhat/rhel5-guide-i731.pdf

I’m going to wager lots of readers spend a great deal of time in the console, and why not when so many powerful tools exist all just a keystroke away? This post is collecting useful command line tools, a few of which I’d not come across before. Particularly good starting point if you’re new to the command line.

http://kkovacs.eu/cool-but-obscure-unix-tools

Everyone is probably vaguely (or intimately) familiar with the Unix Process model. Adam Wiggins of Heroku has been writing about applying this approach to web applications, in particular as an approach to scaling up a system. The tool mentioned called Foreman looks pretty interesting.

http://adam.heroku.com/past/2011/5/9/applying_the_unix_process_model_to_web_apps/

A nice long form article by Jez Humble aimed at CIOs and technical managers. Introducing the ideas behind continuous delivery and other devops tenets, and focusing on the business rationale to make changes.

http://www.cioupdate.com/trends/article.php/3933106/Tired-of-Playing-Ping-Pong-with-Dev-QA-and-Ops.htm

A nice article arguing that, yes, adopting devops practices will probably lead to more work due to unfulfilled demand, but that this is a good thing. And with the right tools, people and processes in place should both drive down costs and drive up profits. Good examples to backup the theme too.

http://www.agileweboperations.com/devops-driven-demand

It’s easier to build apps upon apps with advances in APIs and simpler to fire up new servers in cloud environments either inside or outside your company. This proliferation and speed makes traditional business continuity planning harder argues this article. Getting ahead of this potential problem is something worth thinking about for any growing organisation.

http://www.jpmorgenthal.com/morgenthal/?p=256

Having system metrics is important, but without application level monitoring your users can have problems even while you think your servers are fine. This article walks through a great example with graphs and diagrams showing exactly how this comes about.

http://highscalability.com/blog/2011/5/11/troubleshooting-response-time-problems-why-you-cannot-trust.html

Tools

FPM saw a few more releases this last week, amongst other things adding the ability to very easily convert Python packages from PyPi or local directories to DEBs or RPMs.

https://github.com/jordansissel/fpm/wiki/ConvertingPython

Splinter looks a interesting Python based web functional testing tool. It looks a little like Capybara in Ruby, and provides three drivers for chrome, firefox and the python zopetestbrowser. The blog post demonstrates using it with Lettuce which is a Python BDD framework similar to Cucumber.

http://splinter.cobrateam.info/
http://cilliano.com/blog/2011/02/07/django-bdd-with-lettuce-and-splinter/

entry.title: Issue 21 - 14th May 2011
entry.content:
Issue 21 – 14th May 2011

A few days late but a bit of a bumper issue. We’ve also passed the 1000th subscriber so welcome to everyone who has joined recently.

News

Devopsdays Boston have released all the videos from the talks given so if you could’nt make it along you can catch up on topics ranging from culture to devops in government and much talk of deployment.

http://www.devopsdays.org/events/2011-boston/program/

A few people have started producing Chef recipes and Puppet manifests for installing the full Cloudfoundry vcap stack. I’m much more interested in Vcap that I am another hosted platform and the easier it is to get up and running the better.

https://github.com/auser/cloudfoundry-quickstart
http://www.kartar.net/2011/05/install-cloud-foundry-vcap-via-puppet/

In any distributed system you need a mechanism for the various components to transfer and exchange date efficiently. Both Protocol Buffers (from Google) and Thrift (originally developed at Facebook and now under the Apache banner) are solutions to this problem worth knowing about, and this article does a good job of comparing the technical details of the two.

http://floatingsun.net/articles/thrift-vs-protocol-buffers/

Testing Javascript automatically has often been problematic. The folk at Zendesk have written up how they approach the problem using Jenkins, Jasmine, PhantomJS and JSHint. The post includes some useful rake tasks that you can use to do the same.

http://www.zendesk.com/blog/javascript-loves-ci

Patrick Debois unfortunately missed giving his presentation at goto this last week, but has kindly made the slides available anyway. Damn Abstraction : Development vs Operational Efficiency goes over the the many abstractions we introduce to software projects and management.

http://www.slideshare.net/jedi4ever/damn-abstraction-development-vs-operational-efficiency

Continuous deployment doesn’t have to be hard argues John Wedgwood, with a good post about getting started with a minimum amount of fuss and configuration.

http://www.johnwedgwood.com/continuous-deployment

As a counter point to the above article Jim Bird argues that not only is continuous deployment hard in many environments, it’s also not always a good idea. I liked this in particular because it doesn’t focus on the technical problems as much as the process, security and external relations side of deployments.

http://swreflections.blogspot.com/2011/05/continuous-deployment-is-no-holy-grail.html

Richard Crowley wrote a great article I missed at the start of the year. Arguing good packaging is a thing of beauty and releasing a nifty tool (Debra) which looks a very simple way of approaching the Debian packaging problem.

http://rcrowley.org/articles/packaging.html
http://rcrowley.org/articles/debra.html

Puppet has been around for a good while now and it’s nice to see more and more people writing up good advice. The main thing I took away from this particular article was that learning the whole puppet language, and how to extend it, is a good way of really getting the most out of the tool.

http://nuknad.com/2011/05/10/puppet-lessons-learned/

Tools

Test::Right is described as an opinionated Selenium testing framework. It’s from the folks at Sauce Labs who know a few things about functional testing and aims to lay lots of useful groundwork for writing this sort of test, avoiding many of the common maintenance and tight coupling pitfalls.

https://github.com/saucelabs/test_right

People occasionally comment on the large dependency chain that the Chef server has, and Fatty, from the the Opscode folk, looks to be their answer to this. It appears to be a generic tool that allows for creating a single installable
shell-script that can be executed on the client side. Interesting for some usecases.

https://github.com/adamhjk/fatty

Migrating large databases is hard work, but the folks at Sound Cloud have started releasing some of the tools they’ve been having success with, entertainingly nicknamed the Large Hadron Migrator.

http://backstage.soundcloud.com/2011/05/introducing-the-large-hadron-migrator-3/

Ever wondering what in the network stack is taking up the time for a given HTTP request? Ruok looks a pretty handy little tool for making multiple requests and displaying the time taken for things like DNS lookup, waiting for a connection or SSL.

https://github.com/fr0stbyte/ruok

entry.title: Issue 20 - 5th May 2011
entry.content:
Issue 20 – 5th May 2011

Back to a more health mix of releases, interesting articles, tutorials and tools this week after the deluge of AWS and cloud related experience reports last time. Anyone writing any interesting tools do let me know. If only I had time to try everything out personally.

News

The videos from the previous London Devops event are now available. Big thanks to Adam, Ryan and Squirrel at YouDevise for letting us use their offices and for producing the videos. And thanks to Spike Morelli and James Hogarth for the two talks on Monitoring aided development and on Spacewalk.

http://vimeo.com/22652468
http://vimeo.com/22653015

Really excellent article from Adam Wiggins of Heroku about growing development teams. It’s often missed amongst all the technology that scaling is also about scaling people, most organisations as requests, code bases and servers grow so does the team of people responsible for them.

http://adam.heroku.com/past/2011/4/28/scaling_a_development_team/

A big Chef release landing this week. With 0.10.0 you get much better console behaviour, the new environments concept, easier ways of ignoring files when distributing them to nodes and encrypted data bags amongst other changes and fixes. If you’re running your own Chef server you’ll need to rebuild your search index though.

http://www.opscode.com/blog/2011/05/02/chef-0-10-0-released/

The folks at Puppet Labs are conducting a survey around devops practices. If you have a few minutes to answer a few questions I’m sure the results will be interesting.

http://svy.mk/jNImMz

The long discussed Puppet move to use the Apache 2.0 licence instead of the GPL has now happened. For most this probably makes no difference at all, although we might be some more interesting products integrated with puppet in the future because of the change.

http://www.puppetlabs.com/blog/relicensing-puppet-to-apache-2-0/

PHP and PHP programmers often get quite a big of stick but it’s still a language which sees lots of use, so it’s good to see comprehensive articles aimed at getting PHP folk up and running with continuous integration. Some pretty nice tools used here for static analysis to code smells.

http://erichogue.ca/2011/05/03/continuous-integration-in-php/

I’ve just found this article, from Mark Mayo and written in 2008, about the impending change in both the hosting environment and the role of the sysadmin. Describing the need for sysadmins to move more towards development, virtualisation and web native protocols. All still very relevant today.

http://www.vmunix.com/mark/blog/archives/2008/10/17/cloud-computing-is-a-sea-change-how-sysadmins-can-prepare/

Post from Damon Edwards about the risk of seeing devops as winning the fight for adoption. Depending on who you talk to either everyone is already doing all these things we’re talking about or no-one has even heard of any of them. Timely reminder that evangelism is still needed.

http://www.agileweboperations.com/2011_escaping_devops_echo_chamber

Amazon have written a pretty comprehensive outline of what went wrong, what they are doing to make it less likely in the future and offering affected customers some free service. They acknowledged communications issues during the outage and talk about how they’ll improve that in the future.

http://aws.amazon.com/message/65648/

Quick roundup of popular of unix based orchestration tools. Anyone automating a few boxes would probably benefit from having one of these in their toolkit.

http://www.infoq.com/news/2011/05/unix-orchestration

Tools

Rump looks an interesting addition for anyone using puppet. It brings with it a git based workflow and command line tool for easily running the client and pushing out changes to remote clients. Presentation from the recent puppetcamp and code available.

http://www.slideshare.net/auxesis/rump-making-puppetmasterless-puppet-meaty
https://github.com/railsmachine/rump

entry.title: Issue 19 - 27th April 2011
entry.content:
Issue 19 – 27th April 2011

I’m not sure whether it’s just because I’m on holiday and have more time on my hands or whether it’s just been a busy week but lots of news and interesting tool releases this last week.

News

As I was busy sending the last issue Amazon AWS was having some rather epic issues. While everyones boxes where inaccessible people used the time to write blog posts about the downtime. The High Scalability blog has about 50 articles.

http://agilesysadmin.net/ec2-outage-lessons
http://highscalability.com/blog/2011/4/25/the-big-list-of-articles-on-the-amazon-outage.html

Twilio use EC2 extensively but had very few issues, due to focusing on the principal of a “unit-of-failure is a single host”. This had meant they had avoided using EBS to avoid such a problem.

http://www.twilio.com/engineering/2011/04/22/why-twilio-wasnt-affected-by-todays-aws-issues/

Jordan Sissel gave a talk about fpm at the recent BayLISA event. It’s a great slide desk, laying down the problems with various forays in packaging and then showing code examples of using fpm to build debs and rpms.

https://docs.google.com/present/view?id=0Aa9liCTsAyzRZGNtd3dkOTRfMTdmczY2azlkcg&hl=en&pli=1

Nice write up by Mujtaba Hussain of mixing developers and operations staff members up a little, by loaning team members to different divisions to try and get better communication. Some good discussion in the comments too about what’s worked for other people.

http://techblog.realestate.com.au/2011/04/devops-and-associated-thoughts/

Common patterns for software build and release sounds like a great idea, and Julian Simpson wrote an article for the Spring 2011 issue of Methods & Tools on just that, based on conversations at last years SPA Conference in London.

http://www.methodsandtools.com/archive/archive.php?id=116

Obligatory Vagrant article this time again with a thorough write up of the benefits and purpose of Vagrant, as well as a big Drupal example. This is probably the first time I’ve seen a shared Vagrantfile, which is a great idea come to think of it.

http://chuckdantonio.com/blog/2011/04/add-vagrant-your-team
https://github.com/crdant/vagrant-drupal

Graphite looks pretty interesting for adhoc graphing duties, but the installation and setup isn’t trivial. This article walks through all the steps and looks like it’s going to turn into a series about using Graphite. Look forward the the next one.

http://agiletesting.blogspot.com/2011/04/installing-and-configuring-graphite.html

Tools

Virtual Machine Test Harness is an interesting take on writing tests for configuration management tools. Uses KVM under the hood to take snapshots at different states for testing against. Lacking documentation at the moment though.

https://github.com/gregretkowski/vmth

The folks at Rackspace have released a preview of their open source deployment tool, Cast. It’s an API driven Node.js application which aims to let you automate deployment of applications and services, although it feels odd that the example given is for Redis rather than say a web application.

http://cast-project.org/faq/

Pulp is a Python application for managing software repositories and their associated content, such as packages, errata, and distributions. Another tool in this area from RedHat.

http://pulpproject.org/

entry.title: Issue 18 - 21st April 2011
entry.content:
Issue 18 – 21st April 2011

Another busy week, with lots of interesting tools, announcements and goings on. As I write this issue Amazon EC2 is having some nasty downtime issues. Hopefully next week I can feature some good advice on how to run things across multiple zones more easily and mitigate such problems. Anyone still staring at the AWS status dashboard rather than sleeping has my thoughts.

News

VMWare announced what they’ve been working on of late, and it’s an open source platform as a service. It currently runs Java, Ruby and Node.js applications with hopefully more on the way.

http://www.cloudfoundry.com/

If you’re interested in playing with OpenStack, like anything else it’s useful to be able to do so locally. This article covers settings up the whole OpenStack platform under Virtualbox.

http://uksysadmin.wordpress.com/2011/02/17/running-openstack-under-virtualbox-a-complete-guide/

The recent London CI meetups have been excellent. I was out of town for the last one but luckily the video of Chris Read talking about evolving Continuous Delivery is already up online. Worth watching.

http://skillsmatter.com/podcast/agile-testing/a-sneak-preview-of-evolving-continuous-delivery/js-1600

Lots of companies are both taking the build process more seriously and also often looking to take that responsibility and place it in the hands of one person. Kief Morris writes up why this is a bad idea, and why distributing this across a development team is important.

http://grokandroll.com/Build_Monkey_Antipattern.html

A well put together tutorial with clear code examples and good screen shots. It covers installing software (in this case Drizzle) onto EC2 using Chef.

http://posulliv.github.com/2011/04/07/drizzle-chef.html

The idea of a development environment on demand using Vagrant is one I’m pretty keen on. This article again introduces the tool as well as pointing out a couple of issues the author ran into in getting things up and running.

http://biven.org/writing/dev_on_demand_with_vagrant/

If you’re in the position to be looking at different configuration management tools this product matrix might be useful. It covers a wide range of tools in some detail.

http://distrinet.cs.kuleuven.be/software/sysconfigtools/overview

John Vincent is looking for some feedback on what the Operational primitives are in peoples workflows, specifically related to the tool Noah that’s in development.

http://lusislog.blogspot.com/2011/04/operational-primitives.html

A good reminder that using trending data collected in tools like Ganglia or Collectd is perfect for powering alerting in tools such as Nagios. If you’re not already going this it’s a great idea.

http://vuksan.com/blog/2011/04/19/use-your-trending-data-for-alerting/

A week to go until the deadline for paper proposals for a special issue of Cutters to be edited by Patrick Debois. This looks particularly interesting as the list of topics is all about culture, not technology.

http://www.cutter.com/content-and-analysis/journals-and-reports/cutter-it-journal/callforpapers03.html

Tools

Increasingly some projects are encouraging folks to install software by running a remote shell script. This might be evil in many ways but folks are using it so I’m glad a project like Gosh exists. Gosh gives you a bit of an insight into the code you’re about to execute.

https://github.com/sstephenson/gosh

In a one man war against the failings of ruby packaging Jordan Sissel has been working on a simple way of creating system packages from RVM builds. Very promising.

https://github.com/jordansissel/rvm-packaging

entry.title: Issue 17 - 11th April 2011
entry.content:
Issue 17 – 11th April 2011

Sorry for the delay in getting this issue out, but I hope stuffing it with even more good content will compensate a little. I spent the end of last week in Edinburgh for the Scottish Ruby Conference and, as well as watching some pretty good talks, met a few subscribers and talked an awful lot about Chef, Puppet and Vagrant. Good to meet everyone I bumped into.

News

I always found Varnish documentation by jumping between mailing lists and various bits of the internet, for most things I’ll now probably go to this epic blog post. It doesn’t just cover the obvious caching of static files, but demonstrates more advantages tricks with dynamic content.

http://devblog.factual.com/practical-guide-to-varnish

John Allspaw’s latest post is a pretty thought provoking read, attempting to introduce Resilience Engineering and position it at the heart of how business prioritises activities. It’s part I as well so presumably more on the subject on the way.

http://www.kitchensoap.com/2011/04/07/resilience-engineering-part-i/

Rackspace have rolled out a load balancer feature for their cloud stack. This article covers the details of setting it up for use with other Rackspace cloud instances.

http://cloudservers.rackspacecloud.com/index.php/Configuring_a_Cloud_Load_Balancer

Sometimes it’s just useful to have a big old list of bullet points to remind you about a broad topic. This post from Ricky Ho could be useful if you don’t know where to start, although it would be nice to see lots more references.

http://architects.dzone.com/news/scalable-system-design-0

Replay Solutions carried out a survey of companies, focusing on management and larger organisations around devops. This might be useful to those fighting the good fight and needing to convince the powers that be. The survey results are available as a PDF from that page.

http://replaysolutions.com/company/news/59

I’m finding more and more long, well thought out posts that I’m sure I’ll be referring back to again and again. This post from Stephanie Dean covers processes and practices to use and put in place when everything around you is going wrong. It ends with a great list of responsibilities for the different groups involved that everyone should read.

http://stephaniekdean.wordpress.com/2011/04/04/eventmgmt/

Altering based on a percentage is pretty common, and is the default in many popular monitoring applications. It’s also counter productive and sometimes dangerous according to Chris Siebenmann. He argues very well that the defaults exist because it’s easy to do, and as someone who has been warning about a machine with 20GB of disk left in the past because of this I’m coming round to the same viewpoint.

http://utcc.utoronto.ca/~cks/space/blog/sysadmin/NoAlertOnPercentages

More and more folks are writing up their continuous deployment setups, which I think is a great think. The more shared experience the more we can get to a stage where common tools for things like this exist, lowering the costs and barriers to entry.

http://prettyprint.me/2011/01/24/continuous-deployment-at-outbrain/

Tools

If you’re a fan of using monit, daemon, logrotate and cron for running daemonised services then it’s probably not because of the setup and configuration. pmonit caught my eye as a painless looking approach to getting these all working together quickly. Although I’d be tempted to pull some of this out into Chef recipes or Puppet manifests.

https://github.com/emgee/pmonit

Excellent blog post and application code from Posterous. They ran into issues around optimising caching, and build some pretty impressive tools to allow log play back and generate statistics on cache behaviour.

http://technology.posterous.com/planning-and-engineering-your-cache-for-maxim-0 and https://github.com/vincentchu/sim_cache

Most people who end up talking about low level monitoring of Java applications always sound angry. This tool acts as a connector between JMX and a number of different monitoring systems including cacti, rrdtool, graphite and plain old stdout.

http://code.google.com/p/jmxtrans/

entry.title: Issue 16 - 31st March 2011
entry.content:
Issue 16 – 31st March 2011

I’ll start this issue with a bit of a call to action. It turns out that the Devops Wikipedia page needs some love. It’s led to a few confused views this last week or so and as more and more people come across the term it’s something folks will turn to. It would be great if the community chipped in on http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DevOps. Onwards to the real content.

News

I always love posts where people describe, ideally with diagrams, how a system architecture works. Digg posted this interesting blog post this week doing just that. It goes into a little detail about the services they use and the technology stack they employ. More posts are promised as well.

http://about.digg.com/blog/how-digg-is-built

Patrick Debois has been pushing Vagrant in a small team setup and a complex application with great results. The post is a great walkthrough of the how and why, this some good observations about using a tool like vagrant in a team setting.

http://jedi.be/blog/2011/03/28/using-vagrant-as-a-team/

I’ve been showing various people Chef recently and one problem a few people have commented on is the discoverability of some of the documentation. Sean OMeara pointed out that the docs are vast and broken up into many pages on the Opscode wiki and wrote up a great index along with a brief explanation of each of the main topics.

http://blog.afistfulofservers.net/post/3889872012/a-can-of-condensed-chef-documentation

One thing driving lots of the talk around devops is the move towards software as a service, whether that means inside a large company or paying a third party for an internet based setup. This post has some nice observations about the changes needed if you’re more familiar with the more traditional software delivery process.

http://omniti.com/seeds/from-making-software-to-running-saas

R.I.Pienaar continues his self appointed task of making monitoring better. I’m liking the sound of a framework that can build monitoring systems, meaning you’ll have to add code to the mix to get something useful but that should be specific to your needs, and able to evolve with you over time.

http://www.devco.net/archives/2011/03/25/monitoring_framework_event_correlation.php

Nice writeup of DevOps ATL in Atlanta. Some good points about how particular pain points and skunkworks projects, especially in larger more formal organisations, can help embed newer practices.

http://www.puppetlabs.com/blog/the-state-of-devops-down-south-tips-on-deploying-devops-practices/

I always like being reminded why something is important. These slides on continuous integration are a good read, or maybe something to sent to your boss or colleagues who are interested in the subject.

http://www.slideshare.net/o19s/turbocharge-your-automated-tests-with-ci

Tools

Twitter released the Murder deployment tool using BitTorrent a while ago. Russ Garrett has just released a Python variant of the idea, but with fewer opinions about how you’ll use it. As Russ put it “It was designed for pushing code out to a number of production systems. You can probably use it for other things.”

https://github.com/russss/Herd

entry.title: Issue 15 - 24th March 2011
entry.content:
Issue 15 – 24th March 2011

This issue contains the word metrics repeatedly and it seems more and more we’re focused on gathering data to make the case for what we’re trying to do. That might be code or infrastructure changes or wholesale business improvement, but all things considered this analytical approach feels like a good thing to me. But then my background was as an experimental Physicist so I’m probably biased.

News

A big part of devops is organisational change, and metrics provide a good discussion point to try and prove why change is needed. But metrics can be used for the opposite reason, eloquently described here as using metrics as a weapon.

http://www.hollenback.net/index.php/JustifyingChanges

The idea of writing tests for configuration management has been around for a while but this take on it looks particularly interesting. Using cucumber to make assertions based on puppet providers looks a pretty simple approach code wise.

http://www.unixdaemon.net/tools/puppet/puppet-cucumber-providers.html

DevOpsDays Boston 2011 sounded like it was a great event and this writeup of one of the openspace events sounds interesting. 20 people spoke about using metrics for tracking the effects of changes in your Dev / Ops environments and jotted down a pretty good list of interesting things to track.

http://www.zeroturnaround.com/blog/how-to-measure-the-effectiveness-of-implementing-devops/

More good Vagrant tutorials, this time with a really good end to end PHP example going from the why to a full set of Puppet manifests for bootstrapping a symphony development environment.

http://www.theodo.fr/blog/2011/03/start-using-vagrant/

The Moving Fast at Scale microconference at SXSW looked like one of the highlights of the week and the increasingly nice folks at Etsy have released all the slides from the event. These covered Scaling Startups, Continuous Deployment, Etsy’s inhouse deployment tool Deployinator and talk of Metrics-driven Development.

http://codeascraft.etsy.com/2011/03/19/moving-fast-at-scale-slides-and-reprise/

However much you love Nagios (or your monitoring tool of choice) it likely feels somewhat dated when it comes to dealing with a modern dynamic infrastructure where new machines come and go regularly and often automatically. R.I.Pienaar has been prototyping a new monitoring system that aims to solve that problem as well as potentially many others. One to keep an eye on.

http://www.devco.net/archives/2011/03/19/thinking_about_monitoring_frameworks.php

One aspect of Devops is definitely self improvement, and this article about steps to improve as a sysadmin is interesting, the focus on tasks that might historically simply been shunted to developers in particular.

http://cwebber.ucr.edu/2011/03/the-journey-to-senior-sysadmin/

Tools

Stackops is a distro based on Ubuntu 10.04 LTS Server that allows for installing the various components of the OpenStack Nova platform via a simple to use installer. If Openstack is the ‘Linux’ of the cloud operating systems, StackOps wants to be the reference distribution of this operating system which seems a nobel and lofty goal.

http://blog.stackops.com/2011/03/23/stackops-distro-smart-installer-deploy-openstack-in-your-datacenter/

If you’re deploying applications to Heroku, then Heroku-Bartender might be of interest. It’s a very simple continuous deployment tool which shows you all the commits to a given Git branch and allows you to trigger a deployment of one via a web interface.

http://code.dblock.org/ShowPost.aspx?id=186

entry.title: Issue 14 - 17th March 2011
entry.content:
Issue 14 – 17th March 2011

More interesting news and tools from last week. If anyone has anything they think would be of interest to folks do let me know at gareth@morethanseven.net

News

I finally managed to get a site built this week to provide a list of Vagrant base boxes. The question comes up on Twitter or blog posts or mailing lists pretty regularly. Hopefully a few people find it useful.

http://www.vagrantbox.es/

Amazon have just expanded their virtual networking for Amazon EC2, adding in lots more functionality which to my mind make it much more useful. You can now run with a single public subnet, with public and private subnets, with Internet and VPN access or with VPN access only.

http://aws.typepad.com/aws/2011/03/new-approach-amazon-ec2-networking.html

Dean Wilson has been doing some interesting things around testing deployments and infrastructure changes using Nagios, and NRPE Runner looks a handy tool if you’re interested in doing the same. The basic premise is to have a command allowing you to run your nagios checks like a test suite.

http://www.unixdaemon.net/tools/commandline/introducing-nrpe-runner.html

Ted Dziuba’s latest article covers what and why to monitor, and what makes for a good system that can be easily checked. The focus of monitoring checks should be to keep them Informative and Actionable, which I like.

http://teddziuba.com/2011/03/monitoring-theory.html

Zed Shaw always writes good opinion pieces and this one has a number of good points. The basic gist is that more programmers should actually learn how statistics really works, which I have to agree with. The more we look for evidence for application or process improvements the more important it is to get the analysis right.

http://zedshaw.com/essays/programmer_stats.html

A pretty formal article introducing some folks to the concepts behind Devops. I’m quite interested in the idea that Devops might be a sort-of bridge between IT Service management with Agile development practices

http://www.cmcrossroads.com/behaviorally-speaking/13925-behaviorally-speaking-devops-101

Branches are an important part of lots of development workflows, and with the increasing adoption of version control for configuration management file and the mantra of “infrastructure as code” some people are starting to talk about how to use branches for these too.

http://blog.carlossanchez.eu/2011/03/15/new-challenges-from-devops-development-cycle-for-your-infrastructure/

Tools

The nice folks at Etsy continue releasing various useful tools, this time Logster is a very handy looking tool for parsing log files and generating metrics for Graphite and Ganglia from the results.

https://github.com/etsy/logster

entry.title: Issue 13 - 9th March 2011
entry.content:
Issue 13 – 9th March 2011

News

Maciej Ceglowski has written up the full story of the days and nights when the internet descended on Pinboard after Yahoo attempted to kill off Delicious. All sorts of good recommendations and observations about running a site under load.

http://pinboard.in/blog/173/

Being both a big fan of testing and of monitoring I’ve been thinking for a while about all the parallels between the two. This blog post by Grig Gheorghiu covers just that, expanding on a number of similarities. I’d have liked to see mention of overlapping tools or the lack thereof as I’ve been meaning to write something on that myself for a while.

http://agiletesting.blogspot.com/2011/03/monitoring-is-for-ops-what-testing-is.html

The analysts have been writing interesting things about the whole devops idea and I thought this set of observations from a large IBM event were interesting.

http://blogs.forrester.com/dave_west/11-03-09-dev_ops_fell_on_deaf_ears_at_ibm_pulse_2011

Interesting article from Erwin Bolwidt about what he terms Stateless Computing. This goes into more details, along with a clear outline of the advantages and some practical tips, on using an image based deployment approach.

http://blog.worldturner.com/worldturner/entry/stateless_computing

Jesse Robins from Opscode gave what sounded like a great talk at DevopsDays Boston called Devops Culture Hacks. Martin J. Logan was on hand to live blog it in detail, covering various ways you can help create real change in organisations that already have a way of working.

http://devops.com/2011/03/08/devops-culture-hacks/

On the 19th of May in London UKUUG are running a full day workshop on Debian packaging run by Phil Hands. This sounds like a great way of getting starting with system packaging if you’re wondering where to start.

http://www.ukuug.org/events/debian2011/

Mytop has been around for a long time, but it’s nice to see an introductory article showing how to use it for those that might not have come across it before.

http://www.junauza.com/2011/02/live-performance-monitor-for-your-mysql.html

Tools

Fabric now has a 1.0 release, including improvements to the main workhorses of sudo, run, put and get. Also puts in place some of the groundwork for writing tests for fabfiles and task namespacing in the near future.

http://readthedocs.org/docs/fabric/en/1.0.0/changes/1.0.html

Knife is the command line tool used for managing Chef nodes and it’s now been much improved for those using Windows environments. Knife-windows adds commands to bootstrap and run commands on remote windows machines.

https://github.com/opscode/knife-windows

I’ve not spent enough time looking at looks like ZooKeeper to see where they fit in, but this article takes on that subject and also introduces an alternative tool, Noah, which looks particularly interesting.

http://lusislog.blogspot.com/2011/03/ad-hoc-configuration-coordination-and.html
https://github.com/lusis/Noah

entry.title: Issue 12 - 1st March 2011
entry.content:
Issue 12 – 1st March 2011

A big thank you to everyone who filled out the survey last week. So far I’ve amassed over 600 responses which should make for some good analysis. Now with interesting devops new for the week.

News

The big news this week was Amazon’s launch of CloudFormation, which is a way of creating templates to describe your infrastructure, which can then be executed to provision EC2 instances and other AWS components automatically.

http://aws.amazon.com/cloudformation/

On hearing about CloudFormation various parts of the internet exploded with comments about how they no longer needed Chef or Puppet, missing the difference between configuration management and provisioning (AWS specific provisioning at that) entirely. Luckily Mitchell Hashimoto (of Vagrant fame) and Stephen Nelson-Smith both came to the rescue.

http://agilesysadmin.net/cloudformation
http://mitchellhashimoto.com/post/3526628232/cloudformation-the-big-picture

R.I.Pienaar meanwhile was busy showing how CloudFormation can be useful (with a great mcollective example) and then breaking down some of the good and bad points about the current implementation.

http://www.devco.net/archives/2011/02/26/mcollective_101_demo_using_aws_cloudformation.php

Node.js got some nice things said about it by the smart folk at SimpleGeo. They argue that Node.js is a good candidate for production services right now and outline some of the reasons they chose it and things they like.

http://highscalability.com/blog/2011/2/22/is-nodejs-becoming-a-part-of-the-stack-simplegeo-says-yes.html

If you’re in Chicago this Saturday you might be interested in a Puppet Hack-a-thon being organised by Martin J. Logan. Two tracks and Puppetlabs founder Teyo Tyree should make for an interesting event.

http://www.meetup.com/devops/events/16513536/

Tools

Tav has reworked the core of Fabric to add all sorts of shiny new features and remove a few scars. An environment variable manager, remote script execution, contexts (more advanced roles and hosts control), parallel deployment, stages, a build-in shell, autocompletion and even colours for output. And some other things too. I really hope this gets merged upstream.

http://tav.espians.com/fabric-python-with-cleaner-api-and-parallel-deployment-support.html

An interesting presentation, that actually works just reading the slides. Interesting alternative to package installation and bootstrapping using Fabric and an extension called Cuisine. And details of system monitoring using Watchdog.

http://www.slideshare.net/ffunction/fabric-cuisine-and-watchdog-for-server-administration-in-python

entry.title: Issue 11 - 22th February 2011
entry.content:
Issue 11 – 22th February 2011

Last week was pretty light on tools so I’ve this week I’ve found all sorts of interesting looking new toys to play with. I’d love to see and stories of success or failure if anyone tries any of these out.

News

I’m constantly interested in how everyone does deployment subtly or wildly differently so I’ve decided to run a survey rather than just base my thoughts on my own personal experience and here say. If you have 5 minutes and have anything to do with deploying web sites or applications then please fill in the following Google form.

http://bit.ly/webdeployment

In many cases you don’t want or can’t have lots of automated small releases as you push code but you do want everything that comes with the workflow around continuous deployment. A good article about terminology, around why the recent book was called continuous delivery and why deployment should maybe have been release.

http://continuousdelivery.com/2010/08/continuous-delivery-vs-continuous-deployment/

Sometimes you just want to be in the bay area and this event on Data Collection and Logging looks great. You’ve probably seen talks about processing data with Hadoop, but how did that data get collected in the first place? Are you using Scribe, Chukwa, or something else? And where are you keeping all that data until you’re ready to process it? What about after you process it?

http://www.meetup.com/SF-Bay-Area-Large-Scale-Production-Engineering/events/15481136/

A pretty interesting argument that devops is a way of insourcing work back into development teams that’s previously been outsourced. Drawing parallels to how agile made testing sexy and got people interested in tooling. Worth a read.

http://www.redmonk.com/cote/2011/02/16/the-developer-landgrab-another-way-to-look-at-devops/

Always nice to see more people talking about vagrant, very quick example but it does contain a link to a Centos base box for the latest version of Vagrant.

http://www.maestrodev.com/blogs/vagrant-is-my-new-best-friend

Nice list of 8 things to think about when deploying mysql databases, with a specific focus on EC2 environments. Not loads of detail but a nice list to have handy if you’re not already a database expert.

http://www.iheavy.com/2011/02/21/deploying-mysql-on-amazon-ec2-best-practices/

Tools

An interesting looking continuous deployment framework that makes use of ZooKeeper. At it’s heart a daemon you install on your production machines and a command to trigger those nodes to pull your latest application from your continuous integration system.

https://github.com/mconigliaro/conveyor

Deployment tools are definitely interesting lots of people at the moment and Meerkatalyst looks like an interesting continuous deployment server allowing developers to deploy ASP.net or Ruby projects. Currently invite only but you can sign up on the site.

http://www.meerkatalyst.com/

Poni describes itself as a systems management tool for defining, deploying and verifying complex multi-node computer systems. It looks like a pretty comprehensive command line tool with cloud provisioning baked in as well.

http://melor.github.com/poni/index.html

And finally yet another deployment tool, this time called Beehive which is written in Erlang and Ruby. Again lots of good examples and documentation for getting started.

http://getbeehive.com/

entry.title: Issue 10 - 15th February 2011
entry.content:
Issue 10 – 15th February 2011

And we’re already onto the 10th edition. To celebrate I’ve gone and paid for an upgrade to my Mailchimp account, meaning that all the links you see should now not be horrible link tracking things. Lots of people complained about that.

News

I’m organising another talks evening in London on the 3rd of March, kindly hosted by the nice folks at youDevise again. We’ll have three talks; one on Spacewalk, one on monitoring and another to be announced. Only a few tickets left.

https://londondevops.eventwax.com/devops-talks

Another London event, this time of the paid variety from Thoughtworks. Jez Humble and Chris Turner, are running a full day workshop on March 10th on continuous delivery.

https://www.regonline.com/builder/site/Default.aspx?EventID=936039

First of a couple of Puppet articles I read with interest this week. This one covers self-classifying puppet nodes, and is a good walkthrough with code examples of using puppet and mcollective.

http://nuknad.com/2011/02/11/self-classifying-puppet-nodes/

The second puppet article, about the best way of separating whether you want something installed and whether you want it running in a puppet module. Some good alternatives and discussion in the comments as well.

http://www.krisbuytaert.be/blog/ensure-running

Lots of devops talk is still focused on the technology and I’m probably as guilty of featuring more technology material than anything else. This article caught my eye this week though on what devops really means to business minded folk.

http://www.evolven.com/blog/devops-misunderstandings-and-how-devops-really-drives-business-needs.html

Migrations are always hairy and this post has some nice details about how Involver moved from AWS recently. Just enough juicy details to be interesting.

http://invalidlogic.com/2011/02/11/how-we-did-a-datacenter-migration-with-no-downtime/

Thought provoking video from Randy Shoup talking at QCon about how programming might evolve as more and more things take advantage of cloud services.

http://www.infoq.com/presentations/Evolving-Programming-for-the-Cloud

Some of the slides from the presentations at FOSDEM are showing up online. I particularly liked Joshua’s Chef 101 and application deployment double presentation. A good introduction in the first half and a detailed look at deploying apps using Chef in the second.

http://www.slideshare.net/jtimberman/fosdem-chef101appdeploy

Tools

Spatula looks an interesting tool for anyone using Chef. It provides a simple command line interface to the Opscode cookbooks stored in the official repository, allowing you to search, get details of and download quickly.

https://github.com/trotter/spatula

entry.title: Issue 9 - 8th February 2011
entry.content:
Issue 9 – 8th February 2011

Welcome to the ninth instalment of Devops Weekly. A little later than intended as I’ve been in Brussels for the FOSDEM conference. But we’re back to being out on Tuesday again.

News

The DevOps Survey 2010 results are in. Over 200 people filled in the survey and the results have been collated and graphed. Worth a look.

http://www.geekle.id.au/2011/01/devops-survey-2010-results.html

Belgium is definitely on a roll when it comes to useful technical events and Load looks to be no exception. It’s in Wilrijk on April 16th-17th and is geared towards Linux sysadmins and people interested in linux administration. A call for papers is up now.

http://www.loadays.org/news/call-presentations

More proof that at least the analysts are listening to people about devops. I’m not convinced that platform as a service is really the answer to everything but the comments in particular are worth reading.

http://blogs.forrester.com/mike_gualtieri/11-02-07-i_dont_want_devops_i_want_noops

Brightbox, the UK based web host, have launched a load balancer component to their cloud hosting platform. Unlike Amazon ELB you can point an IP address at a load balancer, meaning you don’t have to use CNAME records, which might be useful to some.

http://blog.brightbox.co.uk/posts/cloud-load-balancers-beta

I’m hearing more and more people try to configure systems so they don’t need to ever login to them. This article is a pretty good explanation of how you might come to that conclusion and what you need to think about to make it a reality.

http://me.andering.com/2011/02/03/server-login-considered-harmful/

Some things still take lots of commands and the first step to automating them is to write everything down. This article covers creating a bootable virtual application using VMWare and does just that.

http://blog.worldturner.com/worldturner/entry/creating_a_bootable_virtual_appliance

Tools

Noah is a lightweight node and service registry based on Zookeeper. Zookepper did always strike me as interesting but pretty impenetrable. Noah uses Redis on the backend and is written in Ruby and already looks well documented.

https://github.com/lusis/Noah

Node Control is a node.js based system admin and code deployment too for executing commands on many remote machines in parallel via ssh. I’m finding it interesting that node.js is cropping up more and more as a platform for writing system tools like this.

https://github.com/tsmith/node-control

entry.title: Issue 8 - 28th January 2011
entry.content:
Issue 8 – 28th January 2011

Welcome to the eighth instalment of Devops Weekly. More than 660 people have now signed up and the list is growing every week. Thanks for sticking around and do let me know what you’d like to see more (or less) of.

News

Lots of people are interested in building a shared vocabulary and understanding at the moment, including this take on documenting release management. The author is seeking input from devops flavoured folk so any ideas you have should be welcome.

http://www.erp4it.com/erp4it/2011/01/release-management-integration-pattern-seeking-devops-comments.html

New Relic have a great product for monitoring Java and Ruby applications and publish the odd bit of interesting insight into what they get up to too. They recently moved database servers and documented how they went about it.

http://blog.newrelic.com/2011/01/26/how-do-you-move-more-than-6000-customers-in-2-hours/

FOSDEM is only weeks away and the official site has started publishing a few interviews. Spike, who some people might have seen talk at the last devopsdays event in Hamburg, is talking again this time about monitoring and the transition from being a full time sysadmin to a developer.

http://fosdem.org/2011/interview/spike-morelli

IMVU, who originally described how they went about continuous deployment, have written up how they deal with intermittently failing tests across a rather large test suite. Interesting problem and solution.

http://engineering.imvu.com/2011/01/19/buildbot-and-intermittent-tests/

Puppet Labs is hosting its bi-annual conference for users and developers in Amsterdam on April 28th and 29th. Early bird tickets are available now and the call for papers ends March 6th for those interested in speaking.

http://www.puppetlabs.com/community/puppet-camp/puppet-camp-ams-2011-info

Tools

It’s always nice to be able to experiment with a web API before you jump head long into code and Jazor looks a nice way of pushing and prodding JSON based services when curl isn’t quite the right tool.

http://conigliaro.org/2011/01/24/jazor-a-simple-command-line-json-parsing-tool/

Pallet describes itself as an agile cloud development tool for developers, sysadmins, and operations. It’s a clojure based tool which doesn’t use a central server or require you to install an agent on each node. The blog contains links to good presentation materials and example code.

http://palletops.com/

entry.title: Issue 7 - 21st January 2011
entry.content:
Issue 7 – 21st January 2011

Welcome to the seventh instalment of Devops Weekly. More tools and events this week than news, so if you’re looking for things to spend your time on this should hopefully be a good issue.

News

Fosdem is just weeks away and a specific devops meal out is being organised again for the night before the conference. Last year was a good opportunity to put faces to names so I’ll definitely be along again this year. Register as places are limited.

http://devopsfosdem2011.eventbrite.com/

Puppet Labs are running several masters 3 day courses in Boston and Brussels in the coming weeks. If you’re using puppet and somewhere in the vicinity these might be useful for you or your colleagues.

http://www.puppetlabs.com/events/boston-training-jan-11/ Jan 31 – Feb 2

http://www.puppetlabs.com/events/brussels-training-feb-11/ Feb 8 – Feb 10

A brief glimpse into some of the technical details surrounding how Google do large scale experiments and testing. This blog post has picked up on a few interesting snippets of how Google go about deployment.

http://glinden.blogspot.com/2011/01/experiment-infrastructure-at-google.html

Richard Crawley from Devstructure launched Gimme Servers this week, which is a super simple interface to launching Rackspace cloud instances. If you’ve used the existing web based dashboard you’ll know why this exists.

http://gimmeservers.com/

Amazon launched Elastic Beanstalk, which provides more of a platform as a service layer on top of EC2. At the moment that means an autoscaling tomcat instance along with build in load balancing and auto-scaling of resources based on utilisation. Very nice looking indeed.

http://aws.typepad.com/aws/2011/01/introducing-elastic-beanstalk.html

Shameless self promotion warning. Here’s article I write last week regarding why software developers like me should care more about system packages.

http://morethanseven.net/2011/01/16/Why-developers-should-care-about-system-packages.html

Tools

FPM looks awesome. If you have to deal with gems or node.js npm packages but you’d rather be dealing with rpms or debs, or you have a debian package with some maintainer scripts you’d rather strip out and manage using chef/puppet, then this tool is for you. It’s early days it seems but I’m hoping other input and output formats will be added soon.

https://github.com/jordansissel/fpm/

Nagiosharder is a tool for querying the state of a nagios instance from a nice Ruby API. This looks ideal if you’re trying to show dashboards or reports without the rest of Nagios getting in the way.

https://github.com/railsmachine/nagiosharder

Playing with large data sets is good fun, but managing all the software required might not be your thing. In which case this set of tools from Infochimps might be useful. It’s a series of chef recipes designed specifically for managing Hadoop and Cassandra clusters, including creating and mounting EBS and setting up NFS.

https://github.com/infochimps/cluster_chef

entry.title: Issue 6 - 14th January 2011
entry.content:
Issue 6 – 14th January 2011

Welcome to the sixth instalment of Devops Weekly. I’ve had a few people contact me about putting job opportunities in the list and I’m giving that a go this week. Shout up if don’t like this.

News

Boston is the venue for the next devopsdays conference and you have until February 20th to get your proposals in if you’d like to speak.

http://devopsdays.org/blog/2011/01/08/boston-devopsdays-7-8-march-2011/

Joshua Timberman from Opscode is in London next month to give a 3 day Chef Fundamentals course from 31st of January.

http://agilesysadmin.net/chef-fundamentals

Lots of the tools I generally use work only on Linux or Unix environments but some people are trying to take along of these same ideas into the Windows world. Jon Topper is currently trying to organise a get together in London and asking people when they could meet.

http://www.doodle.com/zx46wyxy79u53pd6

This is a great article re-imaginging stored procedures. DBA’s and developers working more closely together sounds like a good thing.

http://jaksprats.wordpress.com/2010/11/15/datastore-side-scripting-can-prevent-bottlenecks/

If you want a detailed high level description of all the things you could and should be monitoring look no further. Mathias Meyer has written a great article covering the different levels you probably want monitoring and why, along with reference to tools that fit that problem.

http://www.paperplanes.de/2011/1/5/the_virtues_of_monitoring.html

Facebook talking about scaling is always good and these take aways from a talk by Aditya Agarwal, Director of Engineering at Facebook, are interesting reading. It concentrates mainly on how to scale an organisation which I think is just as important as the technology side.

http://highscalability.com/blog/2010/6/10/the-four-meta-secrets-of-scaling-at-facebook.html

Tools

LASIC is a language that facilitates creating and managing systems in a cloud environment. At the moment it only supports Amazon AWS but looks like it might be interesting

http://code.google.com/p/lasic/

Jobs

FreeAgent is a fast growing and hugely popular UK based startup obsessed with building fantastic online accounting software. We’re a small team of smart people looking to hire productive Ruby and Rails developers in Edinburgh or Cambridge. You’ll be working on adding and maintaining features for our existing applications and making sure our software scales up as we inevitably take over the world.

http://www.freeagentcentral.com/company/jobs

Bin Weevils are looking for a new PHP developer/sysadmin to join the team and continue the development of our PHP backed flash-based game. Being able to handle things at extreme scale is kinda fun – it’s a quiet day that does less than 5,000 concurrent users and 10+ million hits on our servers (and that’s a drop in the ocean compared to the CDN and other servers we run). New code is written in the Zend Framework, with use of Nginx, Memcache and also some Java servers. For sysadmin tasks, an appreciation of tools like Chef and Capistrano would be useful.

http://www.binweevils.com

entry.title: Issue 5 - 7th January 2011
entry.content:
Issue 5 – 7th January 2011

Welcome to the fifth instalment of Devops Weekly. Sorry for the slow start this year, I’ve been a little busy getting the new year started (so still no HTML version, sorry). Luckily the internet has been busy too so here’s what I’ve been reading these past few weeks.

News

First off a few upcoming events. If you’re in Paris the second devops meetup is scheduled for the 12th of January.

http://lanyrd.com/2011/paris-devops-meetup-2/

In Chicago a few days later on the 15th of January a Chef Hackathon is being held. This looks like a full day event and some of the Opscode folk are going to be going along.

http://www.meetup.com/devops/calendar/15648262/

This interview with Adrian Cole about Jclouds (a Java library for interacting with cloud services like EC2) has a few interesting points. In particular the build in in-memory version of S3 especially for writing tests against is a nice idea. Worth a read.

http://www.infoq.com/interviews/adrian-cole-jclouds

This next article shows a couple of approaches to having EC2 (or any cloud instance) automatically register with your puppetmaster. Good examples and good explanation of what you’re doing and why.

http://www.codelord.net/2010/12/19/using-puppet-to-automatically-configure-new-ec2-instances/

A good lengthy walkthrough of starting out with Chef. If you’ve been using Chef for a while it’s easy to forget the initial barrier of getting going so I really liked the conversational style and personal experience approach to this tutorial.

http://beacon.wharton.upenn.edu/404/2010/12/chef-out-of-the-gate/

Tools

SSH is probably one of the most useful and used tools in anyones toolbox and the number of tricks and features is surprisingly large. This ever growing blog post is documenting in an easy to read manner all manner of tips and best practices.

http://crunchtools.com/ssh-keychain/

The nice folk at Etsy have open sourced an internal node.js tool they are using to collect and aggregate statistics. StatsD provides a very straightforward interface for collecting arbitrary stats and feeding them into Graphite.

https://github.com/etsy/statsd

I’m always interested in another continuos integration server and Big Tuna looks nice. It’s a Rails based application, supports multiple version control systems and has a nice looking interface.

http://bigtuna.appelier.com/

entry.title: Issue 4 - 21st December 2010
entry.content:
Issue 4 – 21st December 2010

Welcome to the fourth instalment of Devops Weekly. I’ll probably be taking a break next week while I’m on holiday, so the next issue should be available in the new year. As always email gareth@morethanseven.net if you have anything you’d like included.

News

The Configuration Management DevRoom at Fosdem next year is looking for talks, anyone interested has until the 8th of January to submit. Presentations are to be formal and not longer than 30 minutes, plus 15
extra for questions (45 in total). Panels with more than one speaker are also of interest.

http://www.puppetlabs.com/blog/call-for-papers-configuration-management-devroom-at-fosdem-2011/

You might not be using either Glassfish or Puppet but I found this article interesting anyway as it’s a good walk though of taking unpackaged software fresh from the developers and going through the steps of packaging and automating installation.

http://blog.screv.com/?p=143

The guys at Devstructure have made lots of changes to their service this week, including moving to a completely free model. It’s an interesting approach to configuration management that’s worth having a look at of you haven’t already.

http://blog.devstructure.com/rebooting-devstructure

I feel bad about including the next article as I wrote it, but I reason it’s interesting to readers of devopsweekly. Even pushing down the time between releases doesn’t remove all of the risk from rolling out new code, that’s where smoke testing comes in. This article walks through an example using cucumber and celerity to do fast, headless, tests to check your deployment worked.

http://sysadvent.blogspot.com/2010/12/day-17-smoke-testing-deployments-using.html

More headless testing, this time using the Jasmine BDD Javascript framework. This article shows how to wire up Rhino to allow you to run javascript tests without a browser, perfect for continuous integration.

http://agile.dzone.com/news/javascript-bdd-jasmine-without

Tools

Mcollective, the build server orchestration or parallel job execution framework, has just released version 1.0.0. It comes with a few minor features and bug fixes but also marks a change in how the software packages will be made available and versioned in the future. Well worth a look.

http://groups.google.com/group/mcollective-users/browse_thread/thread/9c548d321b159627

LinkedIn recently released their deployment automation platform called Glu, which is used to deploy the various different parts of LinkedIn. It’s written in groovy/java but can apparently be used to deploy anything.

https://github.com/linkedin/glu/

entry.title: Issue 3 - 14th December 2010
entry.content:
Issue 3 – 14th December 2010

Welcome to the third instalment of Devops Weekly. Thanks for all the support again this week. If you have any news or tools you think people will find interesting do email me at gareth@morethanseven.net

News

Part of Devops is definitely the adoption of agile practices by operations teams and it’s interesting to read about about peoples experience of managing process in a team of systems administrators.

http://www.rooflabs.com/2010/12/13/using-agile-to-manage-system-engineering/

The Agile Web Operations blog has been putting out a series of Devops posts over the past couple of weeks. The first one this week that caught my eye was John Allspaw’s post about soft skills and the importance of communication and collaboration.

http://www.agileweboperations.com/devops-these-soft-parts

The second article is from James Turnbull on why people really shouldn’t get hung up on the word Devops (as some people appear to do). “The point is making Ops better – one step at a time – and in the process making our lives easier”.

http://www.agileweboperations.com/the-state-of-devops

Probably my favourite article of the week was this one, on the re-emergance of Systems Engineering as a discipline. I found lots of this described me and, I think, many of the people I meet at Devops events. It also neatly sidesteps the Devops as a role argument.

http://www.cuddletech.com/blog/pivot/entry.php?id=1149

James talked in his article above about his formative years and another post this week caught my eye about experience gained working with smart people and processes. This one covers the importance of source control, staging servers and some lessons learned using them. Good introductory material is hard to write so I’d love to see more.

http://www.kalzumeus.com/2010/12/12/staging-servers-source-control-deploy-workflows-and-other-stuff-nobody-teaches-you/

I find people sharing details about the tools they use incredible useful, especially when they can include numbers. This great open blog post about using Bacula for backups is exactly the sort of thing I’d like to see more of. “A standard 2 week rotation amounts to ~190 TB of data con taining ~490.000.000 files”

http://blog.myunix.dk/2010/12/01/large-scale-disk-to-disk-backups-using-bacula/

Just before I hit the send button Julian Simpson just published a good interview with the product manager of the Go continuous integration and deployment pipeline too from Thoughtworks.

http://www.build-doctor.com/2010/12/14/go-thoughtworks-jez-humble/

Tools

I found myself looking at different ways of aggregating log files from different systems this week and had chance to investigate a couple of newish open source offerings.

Graylog2 is a Java app which stores syslog entries in a MongoDB datastore, along with a good looking Ruby on Rails application for looking at the results.

http://www.graylog2.org/

Logstash is similar in purpose to Graylog2 but uses ElasticSearch as the backend. It can also aggregate logs from syslog, text files or AMQP which might prove useful.

http://code.google.com/p/logstash/

entry.title: Issue 2 - 7th December 2010
entry.content:
Issue 2 – 7th December 2010

Thanks for all the feedback since last week. I had a few issues with links being rewritten to be rather on the long side when the final newsletter was sent out. I was hoping to have time this week to get round to resolving but alas the week flew by. The same will happen again this time but I’ve positioned the links after the text so it should be easier to read. I’ll probably move to a very simple HTML format as time permits.

News

It’s December which means we have lots of blogs trying to publish a new article every day. One such blog that I found last year and is keeping up the high standard again is SYSADVENT. The pick of the articles for me so far has been this one, talking about using code reviews in operations teams.

http://sysadvent.blogspot.com/2010/12/day-5-why-arent-you-doing-code-reviews.html

People interested in PERFORMANCE even have their own advent calendar blog, again publishing some really good content already. This article about the need for generalists within software teams I think runs parallel with many of the ideas of devops, at least as I see them.

http://calendar.perfplanet.com/2010/the-full-stack/

A few weeks ago now a group of about 35 London based developers and ops people met up to talk about DEPLOYMENT. The nice folks at YouDevise let us use a room in their offices and we had at it for a good few hours. The videos taken during the event have just been published and make an educational and occasionally entertaining watch.

https://dev.youdevise.com/YDBlog/index.php/2010/12/01/devops-comes-to-youdevise

This isn’t a new article but I found it interesting coming from GARTNER. If you’re working in a large enterprise it can often be tricky to get buy-in for new ideas or ways of working. Having large companies outside the technology sector as well as analyst firms advocating for some of the things we’re all talking about can only be beneficial.

http://blogs.gartner.com/cameron_haight/2010/04/07/the-need-for-it-io-reform/

Matthew Jones has put together a pretty comprehensive SURVEY around devops. We’ve seen lots of people writing about what they think devops means, so it should be interested if enough people fill this out to see what a wider group think.

http://www.geekle.id.au/2010/12/devops-survey-2010.html

Tools

The HUDSON project have been having some political issues of late and it’s good to see them publishing regular updates to the wider community. Continuous Integration plays a big part in quite a few devops ideas and we need a mature open source player in the area.

http://www.hudson-labs.org/content/whos-driving-thing

MCOLLECTIVE has traditionally used ApacheMQ for it’s messaging needs and several people (myself included) had enquired about whether it could work with RabbitMQ, especially for people that already had that message queue in a production environment. With recent patches to the Stomp adaptor for Rabbit, and this handy tutorial you should be up and running in no time.

http://www.threedrunkensysadsonthe.net/2010/12/mcollective-and-rabbitmq-on-centos/

entry.title: Issue 1 - 30th November 2010
entry.content:
Issue 1 – 30th November 2010

Welcome to the first issue of Devops Weekly.

I’ve been finding Ruby Weekly (http://rubyweekly.com/), an email newsletter from Peter Cooper, increasingly useful in the last month or so. Something about finding a small amount of high quality content once a week easier to digest than the usual fire hose of RSS and Twitter. So I’m trying the same format out for devops related content. Please email me with anything you think is worth featuring.

But what is Devops? I know a number of people have signed up to this newsletter having only recently come across the term. It’s safe to say Devops means different things to different people at this early stage, but I’m going to start out by pointing everyone to James Turnbull’s WHAT DEVOPS MEANS TO ME (http://www.kartar.net/2010/02/what-devops-means-to-me/).

News

The much loved VELOCITY conference has put out a call for participation (http://velocityconf.com/velocity2011/public/cfp/137) for next year’s event. You have until January 11th, 2011 to put together suggestions and submit them. In particular they are looking for talks and panels on NoSQL, mobile performance, effective cloud computing, javaScript speedups, TCP, HTTP, and SSL optimizations, metrics and monitoring and the impact on the bottom line.

Lindsay Holmwood has written an interesting piece this week about all the things happening in Devops recently, in particular whether people are too focused on tools and technologies at the expense of people and communication (http://www.agileweboperations.com/devops-hijacked-by-technologists).

On a related topic Spike Morelli has been writing about the use of the term Devops and how it’s a useful marketing phrase if we want to spread our experiments and ideas to a wider audience (http://www.spikelab.org/the-word-devops-and-a-marketing-problem/). This definitely gels with my own reasons for creating Devops Weekly.

Tools

Joe Heck just wrote about a new monitoring system he’s been working on for a year called EYES (http://www.rhonabwy.com/wp/2010/11/20/eyes-a-new-monitoring-system/). It’s still early days but sounds interesting. The main thrust seems to be that having a monitoring system that is completely API driven from the start makes lots of things easier. It uses the Nagios plugin format as well so you should be able to make use of existing plugins easily enough.

I’ve recently been playing with CUCUMER for monitoring purposes and it looks like others have too. Jordan Sissel just posted an example of using Cucumber to monitor a Solr instance (https://gist.github.com/707691) that I found useful. If anyone else has any Cucumber scripts they use for monitoring purposes I’d love to know.

One article I came across this week that I found particularly handy was a huge roundup of Linux MONITORING UTILITIES (http://www.cyberciti.biz/tips/top-linux-monitoring-tools.html). I’d wager most readers will have come across most of the tools on the list but I found it interesting seeing them all listed in one place along with quick examples.

I only came across VAGRANT (http://vagrantup.com/) at the recent devopsdays event in Hamburg but I’m already finding it indispensable. Vagrant is a tool for building and distributing virtualized development environments built around VirtualBox. In my view it massively reduces the barrier to entry for using virtualisation in even small development teams. Worth checking out.

Events

UK SCALE CAMP (http://www.scalecamp.org.uk/) is billed as a one-day event for and by people who care about web performance and scalability. It’s being hosted in London at the offices of The Guardian and if last year’s event was anything to go by should be a great opportunity to talk about interesting topics with smart people. For those not able to make it along I’ll try and find as many write ups of the event for a future Devops Weekly.

Sponsored Link

Well not really, DEVOPS BOOKS (http://devopsbooks.com/) is another site I just launched collecting recommended reading for anyone interested in Devops topics. I’m always looking for more book recommendations so please email me with anything I’m missing.
